message.content:
We begin by “translating” the two sides of the query into explicit chains, using only the relationships provided.

For Judith, the only two facts mentioned are:
• “Gary is Judith’s descendant.”
• “Ann is Gary’s descendant.”

So, we know at least that
 Judith → Gary → Ann → … 
(In fact, additional relationships connect Ann to further descendants, but none of those names appear on the other side.)

For Deborah, we only have:
• “Deborah is Edward’s descendant.”
• And we also see that “Edward is Jordan’s descendant” and “Jordan is Alice’s descendant,” with “Brittany is Alice’s ancestor.” Thus, one chain is:
 Brittany → Alice → Jordan → Edward → Deborah

When we compare the names on these chains, no name appears in both groups. In other words, from the given facts there is no link that makes Judith an ancestor (or descendant) of Deborah, nor is there any individual stated to be an ancestor of both of them.

Thus, none of the statements (Judith being Deborah’s ancestor, descendant, or sharing a common ancestor or descendant with Deborah) are supported by the provided information.

The correct answer is therefore option 5.

<ANSWER>5</ANSWER>
